original: Contract ProvisionClause Requirements for Adequate Assurance of Protection of Vertebrate Animal SubjectsThe PHYS Policy on Humane Care and Use of Laboratory Animals requires that applicant organizations proposing to use vertebrate animals file a written Animal Welfare Assurance with the Office for Laboratory Animal Welfare (OLAW), establishing appropriate policies and procedures to ensure the humane care and use of live vertebrate animals involved in research activities supported by the PHS.  The PHS Policy stipulates that an applicant organization, whether domestic or foreign, bears responsibility for the humane care and use of animals in PHS-supported research activities.  Also the PHS policy defines “animal” as “any live, vertebrate animal used, or intended for use, in research, research training, experimentation, biological testing or for related purposes.”  This policy implements and supplements the U.S. Government Principles for the Utilization and Care of Vertebrate Animals Used in Testing, Research, and Training, and requires that institutions use the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals as a basis for developing and implementing an institutional animal care use program.  This Policy does not affect applicable State or local laws or regulations that impose more stringent standards for the care and use of laboratory animals.  All institutions are required to comply, as applicable, with the Animal Welfare Act, as amended and other Federal statutes and regulations relating to animals. These documents are available from the Office of Laboratory Animal Welfare, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20892, (301) 496-7163. http://grants.nih.gov/grants/olaw/olaw.htm.
ollama_generated:
Contract Provision: Obligation for Appropriate Measures in the Protection of Vertebrate Animal Subjects

The PHYS Policy on Humane Care and Use of Laboratory Animals expects that applicant organizations, whether domestic or foreign, will submit a written Animal Welfare Assurance to the Office for Laboratory Animal Welfare (OLAW), outlining suitable policies and procedures to guarantee the humane treatment of live vertebrate animals participating in research activities supported by the PHS. The onus lies with the applicant organization to ensure the ethical treatment of animals in PHS-funded research projects. As per the PHS Policy, an "animal" is defined as any living, vertebrate creature intended for use in research, training, experimentation, biological testing, or related activities.

This policy serves to uphold and supplement the U.S. Government Principles for the Utilization and Care of Vertebrate Animals Used in Testing, Research, and Training. Institutions are advised to base their animal care and use programs on the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals.

However, this policy does not supersede any more rigorous state or local laws and regulations concerning the handling of laboratory animals. All institutions must adhere, as necessary, to the Animal Welfare Act, as amended, and other pertinent federal statutes and regulations regarding animal care. The relevant documents for these requirements can be obtained from the Office of Laboratory Animal Welfare, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20892, (301) 496-7163. http://grants.nih.gov/grants/olaw/olaw.htm.

In this revised version, the responsibility for ensuring humane treatment of animals has been shifted from the PHS to the applicant organization, and the clause now outlines expectations rather than requirements.
